title: 33 Natural Ways to Improve Mitochondrial Function - SelfDecode Health
author: Joe Cohen; BS
description: Want to learn to optimize mitochondrial function and improve health through diet, lifestyle, and supplementation? Read on for the top hacks.
cleaned_text: Some scientists believe there are many ways to optimize mitochondrial function by changing diet, lifestyle, and supplementation. Improving mitochondrial health may boost energy levels and improve physical health and immunity. Some people think it might even increase their lifespan. But what does the science say? Read on for a breakdown of the evidence. Mitochondrial Function How is Mitochondrial Function Improved? Scientists hypothesize that supplements and lifestyle changes can improve mitochondrial health by increasing the availability of proteins needed for ATP production (AMPK activation, PCG-1a, [NAD+](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/nad-important-increase/), [SIRT1](https://selfhacked.com/blog/nad-and-sirt1-their-role-in-chronic-health-issues/)/3). They also act as antioxidants, assisting the [mitochondria](https://selfhacked.com/blog/mitochondria/) in reducing oxidative stress [ [1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28778860)]. Some of the following lifestyle changes and supplements may also increase the number of mitochondria present within the cell, according to limited evidence. However, remember to speak to your doctor before taking dietary supplements or making any major changes to your lifestyle. You may try the complementary strategies listed below if you and your doctor determine that they could be appropriate. None of these strategies should ever be done in place of what your doctor recommends or prescribes. Additionally, supplements have not been approved by the FDA for medical use and generally lack solid clinical research. Regulations set manufacturing standards for supplements but don't guarantee that they're safe or effective. Speak with your doctor before supplementing. Lifestyle Changes That May Improve Mitochondrial Function 1) Intermittent Fasting Restricting calories and [ fasting intermittently](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/intermittent-fasting/), such as for fixed hours of the day, decreases energy levels in the body. To compensate, levels of [ NAD](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/nad-important-increase/)+ increase, which increases the ability of the mitochondria to produce ATP. This results in a subsequent rise in ATP levels due to improved mitochondrial function. This is still only a scientific hypothesis, though [ [2](http://jcb.rupress.org/content/199/2/205.full)]. 2) Exercise In a similar manner to calorie restriction and fasting, exercising depletes energy from the body. This, in turn, improves mitochondrial function by increasing the availability of NAD+ molecules required to make ATP, according to some scientists [ [2](http://jcb.rupress.org/content/199/2/205.full)]. Additionally, [ exercise](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/top-14-proven-health-benefits-exercise-references-mechanisms/) requires energy from the muscles to power through and provides oxygen throughout the body. Continuous exercise increases the number of mitochondria in muscle cells so that adequate ATP levels can be provided for use during exercise [ [3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19448716)]. In fact, one study in 8 healthy elderly volunteers found just 2 weeks of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) significantly increased mitochondrial function in the muscle. Additional studies should be encouraged [ [4](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1540458/)]. 3) Cold Exposure [Cold](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/12-reasons-embrace-cold/) temperatures have a profound effect on the mitochondrial number in animals. Exposing rats to swimming in cold temperatures (23°C) increased mitochondrial generation by increasing the protein responsible for initiating mitochondrial synthesis ( [PGC-1alpha](https://selfhacked.com/blog/about-pgc-1alpha-and-natural-ways-to-increase-it/)) [ [5](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28715885)]. Similar results were seen in rats' liver and skeletal muscle cells after cold exposure for 15 days. These findings have not been confirmed in humans [ [6](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15792806)]. 4) Ketogenic diet The [ ketogenic diet](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/ketogenic-diet-keto-diet-ketosis-health-benefits/) is a high-fat, low-carb diet that is claimed to switch your body from running on carbs to running on fats [ [7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24847102)]. When fats are broken down for energy, small molecules called [ ketone bodies](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/ketone-bodies/) are produced. These molecules are used for the production of ATP instead of [ glucose](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/glucose/). Some researchers believe that this results in improved mitochondrial function (PGC-1alpha, [SIRT1](https://selfhacked.com/blog/nad-and-sirt1-their-role-in-chronic-health-issues/)/3, AMPK activation), higher levels of ATP from the electron transport chain, and overall cellular health [ [7](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24847102)]. One study found that a ketogenic diet slowed down mitochondrial myopathy (a muscle disease) in mice in part by increasing the number of new mitochondria (mitochondrial biogenesis). Human studies are lacking [ [8](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20167576)]. Supplements that May Improve Mitochondrial Function 5) Oxaloacetate [Oxaloacetate](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/oxaloacetate/) is an intermediate product produced during the Krebs cycle (see [ mitochondria part 1](https://selfhacked.com/blog/mitochondria/)) and can be purchased as a supplement. In mice, daily injections of oxaloacetate for 2 weeks increased the number of mitochondria in brain cells. This was mediated by increasing the production of proteins responsible for building new mitochondria and improving mitochondrial function. Clinical trials are needed [ [9](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25027327)]. 6) Malic acid Another intermediate of the Krebs cycle, [ malic acid](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/malic-acid/) (AKA malate), has a number of purported health benefits linked to improved mitochondrial function. It is a key step in the pathway of energy production by the mitochondria. In worms, malate supplementation increased the availability of NAD+, which is necessary for producing ATP. Malate also increased [ NADPH](https://selfhacked.com/blog/nicotinamide-adenine-dinucleotide-phosphate-nadph/) levels, which is a fundamental antioxidant in the body that promotes mitochondrial function [ [10](http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0058345)]. [Malic acid](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/malic-acid/) supplementation enhanced strength and endurance during exercise in a study (DB-RCT) of 14 males, likely by improving mitochondrial function. Large-scale studies should replicate these results [ [11](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25674699)]. 7) Resveratrol [Resveratrol](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/top-15-scientific-health-benefits-of-resveratrol-with-references/) is a potent antioxidant used as a supplement for a variety of alleged health benefits. Found naturally in the skin of red grapes, researchers think it might improve mitochondrial function and increase the number of mitochondria per cell. In a rat model of Parkinson's disease, resveratrol prevented neurotoxicity by increasing mitochondrial synthesis and improving mitochondrial function [ [12](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4684867/)]. Similarly, in mice given resveratrol for 15 weeks, resveratrol increased exercise capacity and muscle oxygen consumption. There was also an increase in proteins (SIRT1/PGC-1 alpha/AMPK) that are linked to mitochondrial synthesis and oxidative phosphorylation [ [13](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867406014280)]. Conversely, resveratrol given to both rats and mice for 8 weeks did not show improvements in mitochondrial function or synthesis. This was attributed to low oral absorption of resveratrol, which may be responsible for the lack of effect seen [ [14](http://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.1001603)]. In multiple types of cells, resveratrol increased the levels of proteins (SIRT1/PGC-1 alpha/AMPK) involved in manufacturing new mitochondria [ [15](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3819727/), [ 16](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19429820), [ 17](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4024846/)]. Clinical trials about the effects of resveratrol on general and mitochondrial health are needed. Low bioavailability casts doubt on resveratrol's purported benefits. 8) Apigenin [Apigenin](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/apigenin-top-11-science-based-health-benefits-apigenin/) is a natural substance occurring in many different fruits and vegetables. Apigenin given to obese mice prevented the breakdown of NAD+ and therefore increased levels of NAD+ and SIRT1, a protein involved in both mitochondrial function and genesis [ [18](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23172919)]. In cells exhibiting high levels of stress, mitochondrial function is decreased. The addition of apigenin was able to protect the mitochondria from cellular stress and prevent the loss of mitochondrial function [ [19](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25106896)]. Clinical studies are lacking. 9) Leucine [Leucine](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/leucine-health-benefits-side-effects/) is an amino acid involved in the formation of proteins. It is an essential amino acid, meaning that it is not synthesized by the body and must be obtained from food. Therefore, it is often is supplemented. In obese mice, leucine supplementation for 2 months significantly increased levels of NAD+ and SIRT1, resulting in improved mitochondrial function [ [18](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23172919)]. In muscle and fat cells, leucine increased mitochondrial mass by 30% and 53% respectively. Both increases were caused by leucine's ability to increase SIRT1 [ [20](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2701939/)]. Similarly, in skeletal muscle cells, leucine increased mitochondrial density and improved mitochondrial function [ [21](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23812674)]. More research is needed. 10) Niacinamide Niacinamide, also known as nicotinamide, is a vitamin found in foods and often supplemented or used medically. It forms a major component of [ vitamin B3](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/top-science-based-health-benefits-vitamin-b3-niacin/). Niacinamide is the precursor to NAD+ and thus, supplementation is claimed to increase levels of this molecule and improve mitochondrial function. In rat brains (striatum), niacinamide prevented energy depletion caused by d-amphetamine, a major component of the ADHD drug Adderall [ [22](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10566977)]. Niacinamide may improve mitochondrial quality of cells by causing dysfunctional mitochondria to fragment (autophagy). This effect was seen in human cells, subsequently resulting in reduced levels of mitochondria but maintained functioning, normal mitochondria [ [23](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19473119)]. However, niacinamide clinical studies are lacking. 11) PQQ Pyrroloquinoline quinone, or [ PQQ](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/pqq-review/), is an important molecule found in certain foods and often supplemented for its alleged effects on mitochondrial generation and energy levels. In mice supplemented with PQQ for 8 weeks, mitochondrial function and number were increased significantly. This was seen as an increase in the amount of mitochondrial DNA found in the cells of these mice [ [24](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16424117)]. Multiple cell tests investigated the effects of PQQ on mitochondrial number and function. PQQ seems to alter a number of proteins (increasing SIRT1, promoting PGC-1alpha production and [ CREB](https://selfdecode.com/gene/creb1/?utm_source=seo&utm_medium=selfhacked&utm_campaign=id00002)-phosphorylation) while reducing oxidative stress. These effects remain untested in humans [ [25](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26275361), [ 26](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2804159/), [ 27](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2844438/)]. 12) Lipoic acid Lipoic acid is a naturally-occurring substance that is necessary for energy production via glycolysis. [Lipoic acid](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/lipoic-acid/) reduces age-associated mitochondrial dysfunction and nutrient [ [28](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17605107)]. In mice, alpha-lipoic acid prevented mitochondrial dysfunction caused by hypothermia [ [29](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5293729/)]. In rats, lipoic acid supplementation reduced mitochondrial DNA damage, improved the antioxidant activity of the mitochondria, and increased the number of mitochondria per cell. Overall, rats demonstrated an improvement in mitochondrial function through the activation of SIRT1/3 [ [30](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22327056)]. 13) Berberine Berberine is a compound found in plants and traditionally used in Chinese medicine. Scientists believe [berberine](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/berberine-19-health-benefits-of-berberine-with-references/) has a direct effect on mitochondrial function. However, because berberine accumulates in the mitochondria, high doses may be toxic and can actually induce mitochondrial dysfunction. Additional research is needed [ [31](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21269266), [ 32](http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0107129), [ 33](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18599498)]. In fish fed high-fat diets, berberine supplementation for 8 weeks improved liver mitochondrial function and prevented cell death [ [34](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27497985)]. In skeletal muscle cells, berberine prevented mitochondrial dysfunction by increasing [ SIRT1](https://selfhacked.com/blog/nad-and-sirt1-their-role-in-chronic-health-issues/) levels and subsequently, the generation of new mitochondria [ [35](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3366688/)]. 14) Bitter melon [Bitter melon](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/bitter-melon-9-proven-health-benefits-momordica-charantia-bitter-melon-including-risks/) is a fruit grown in Asian countries that is a powerful antioxidant [ [36](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21639917)]. Scientists suggest that bitter melon can induce proteins that increase mitochondrial manufacturing and function (PGC-1alpha and [ PPAR-alpha](https://selfhacked.com/blog/about-ppar-alpha-and-natural-ways-to-activate-it/)) in cells [ [37](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4306384/)]. In rats fed high-fat diets, bitter melon prevented the loss of mitochondrial function by a process known as mitochondrial uncoupling. During uncoupling, the mitochondria produce heat instead of ATP and this results in a loss of energy to the cell [ [38](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17651527/)]. Similar results were seen in mice, where bitter melon supplementation improved mitochondrial function and reduced oxidative stress. Human studies are needed [ [39](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3135761/)]. 15) Nicotinamide riboside [Nicotinamide riboside](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/nicotinamide-riboside/) is claimed to have a very similar function to niacinamide and acts as a precursor to NAD+. In mice, this supplement increased NAD+ levels and activated mitochondrial generation in skeletal muscle and fat tissue. Additionally, nicotinamide riboside maintained normal levels of mitochondrial DNA and prevented structural abnormalities of the mitochondria. It may be an effective supplement for those suffering from mitochondrial myopathies (muscle disease) [ [40](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24711540)]. Supplementing nicotinamide riboside in human and mouse tissues increased levels of NAD+ and SIRT1. This led to improved energy production and protection against age-related and metabolic issues that lead to loss of mitochondrial function. However, proper clinical trials are lacking [ [41](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22682224)]. 16) Gotu Kola [Gotu kola](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/gotu-kola-2/) is the common name for the plant Centella Asiatica, which is used traditionally in Ayurvedic and Chinese medicine. In old and young rats, Gotu kola for 2 weeks increased the number of mitochondria in brain cells and mitochondrial function. This was linked to its role in improving cognitive function (Morris Water Maze) [ [42](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4764102/)]. In a rat model of Parkinson's disease, gotu kola supplementation for several weeks prevented mitochondrial damage associated with neurotoxicity [ [43](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20118623)]. The exact effects of gotu kola on mitochondrial function in humans has not been studied, but cognitive improvements have been demonstrated in 48 patients who suffered a stroke. This improvement may be a result of gotu kola's protective and regenerative effects on the mitochondria. Additional research is needed [ [44](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4908235/)]. 17) Gynostemma Gynostemma, also known as jiaogulan, is a plant found in eastern Asian countries and is used for a variety of health benefits. In obese mice with mitochondrial dysfunction, [ gynostemma](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/gynostemma-boost-immunity-energy-weight-loss-top-9-benefits/) supplementation for 8 weeks improved energy metabolism by increasing mitochondrial proteins (AMPK) [ [45](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22576281)]. Multiple cell studies have found that gynostemma exhibits an antioxidant effect on cells with mitochondrial dysfunction by modifying specific proteins that play a role in mitochondrial activity (AMPK, cytochrome C, reduced unnecessary 47](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4429198/), [ 48](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24726523)]. 18) Inosine Inosine is a precursor molecule for [ adenosine](https://selfhacked.com/blog/about-adenosine-and-the-adenosine-deaminase-gene-rs73598374/) and is involved in protein production. In brain cells (glial), inosine delayed cell death by increasing the amount of ATP produced by the mitochondria. It, therefore, may improve mitochondrial activity and cell survival [ [49](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9681443)]. 19) C60 [C60](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/fullerene-top-10-benefits-c60-oil/) is the chemical formula for a compound called fullerene. It is an experimental, poorly-researched compound that is sold as a supplement. According to limited research, C60 reduces the effects of free radicals released from the mitochondria. Additionally, C60 improves the activity of the electron transport chain and therefore, the mitochondria's ability to make energy [ [50](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24361870)]. In rats, C60 reduced muscle fatigue associated with a free radical formation in skeletal muscle cells. This is due to its antioxidant activity [ [51](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5237293/)]. In bacterially activated cells, carboxylic acid C60 improved mitochondrial dynamics by inhibiting programmed cell death (apoptosis) and oxidative stress caused by free radical formation [ [52](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4481245/)]. However, C60 may also induce DNA mutations. Thus, C60 has a high potential for harm with unknown risks and side effects. We suggest against supplementation until proper clinical trials determine the effectiveness and safety profile of this substance. 20) MitoQ [MitoQ](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/mitoq/) is a supplement specifically designed to prevent oxidative stress within the mitochondria. It has been studied in limited human trials of Parkinson's disease and hepatitis C, both of which are linked to oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction [ [53](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20649545)]. Parkinson's disease progression is heavily influenced by oxidative stress. In 128 patients with Parkinson's disease (DB-RCT), mitoQ was no more effective than placebo at reducing the progression of Parkinson's [ [54](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20568096)]. However, in 30 patients with hepatitis C (RCT), mitoQ improved liver function and decreased liver damage (alanine transaminase levels) linked to mitochondrial oxidative stress. Further studies are required to demonstrate the effects of mitoQ on humans with different diseases caused by oxidative damage [ [55](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20492507)]. Animal studies in mice, guinea pigs, and rats with conditions caused by oxidative stress have shown that MitoQ supplementation effectively protects against mitochondrial damage and dysfunction [ [56](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24518411), [ 57](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24582549), [ 58](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24665093), [ 59](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25066801)]. Large-scale clinical studies are needed. 21) Butyrate [Butyrate](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/butyrate-health-benefits/) is a molecule found in fatty acids that have many purported health benefits. In mice with [ insulin](https://selfhacked.com/blog/insulin-101/) [ resistance](https://selfhacked.com/blog/2013/11/07/top-tips-for-fixing-insulin-resistance) (a sign of mitochondrial dysfunction), butyrate supplementation for 1 week improved mitochondrial function by increasing energy expenditure [ [60](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2699871/)]. Similarly, in obese mice, butyrate improved glucose metabolism and energy expenditure in the liver. This effect was due to its antioxidant effects, reducing damage to the mitochondria. These effects have yet to be investigated in humans [ [61](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28223285)]. 22) Hydroxytyrosol [Hydroxytyrosol](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/olive-leaf-extract-10-unexpected-health-benefits/) is a compound found in [ olive oil](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/olive-oil/) with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. In rats with breast cancer, hydroxytyrosol improved mitochondrial function in the heart and prevented oxidative stress caused by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin. These findings have not been replicated [ [62](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24727461)]. In mice, 8 weeks of hydroxytyrosol improved mitochondrial function by increasing proteins (SIRT1, AMPK, PPAR-alpha) involved in energy dynamics and reducing oxidative stress [ [63](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25885653)]. Hydroxytyrosol also increased mitochondrial generation through proteins (PGC1-alpha) in fat cells, which led to increased mitochondrial DNA and the number of mitochondria per cell [ [64](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19576748)]. Similarly, multiple cell studies investigated the antioxidant activity of hydroxytyrosol [ [65](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21497591), [ 66](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20149621)]. However, proper clinical trials are lacking. 23) N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) [N-acetyl cysteine](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/nac-top-43-science-based-health-benefits-n-acetyl-cysteine-nac/) is a supplement used for paracetamol overdose, cystic fibrosis, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. In a mouse model of Huntington's disease, NAC treatment for 9 weeks reduced oxidative damage to the mitochondria and delayed the onset of motor dysfunction [ [67](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4312826/)]. Similar effects were seen in a rat model of Huntington's disease [ [68](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22327485)]. In multiple cell studies, NAC was investigated for its effects on mitochondrial function and oxidative stress [ [69](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17917164), [ 70](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4726696/)]. Additional clinical studies are needed. 24) Succinic acid Succinic acid, also known as succinate, is an intermediate molecule of the Krebs cycle that plays a significant role in the electron transport chain. It can be purchased as a supplement to boost energy production by the mitochondria. Limited studies have been conducted on the effects of succinic acid supplementation. In rat liver cells, succinic acid administration prevented structural and functional damage to the mitochondria caused by oxidative stress. It also prevented the release of protein molecules that trigger cell death from the mitochondria [ [71](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3032929)]. In brain cells (glial) that exhibit mitochondrial dysfunction (inability to utilize oxygen and glucose efficiently), succinic acid supplementation improved mitochondrial function by increasing glucose and oxygen usage. This led to increased levels of ATP [ [72](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5430749/)]. 25) Chinese skullcap A plant used in traditional Chinese medicine, [ Chinese skullcap](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/chinese-skullcap/) may benefit mitochondrial function. The effects of Chinese skullcap on mitochondria are being investigated in cells. This herb can increase [ SIRT3](https://selfhacked.com/blog/about-sirt3-and-natural-ways-to-increase-it/), a protein involved in maintaining only normal mitochondria and sensing dysfunctional activity within the cell [ [73](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23337959), [ 74](https://www.nature.com/articles/cddis201414)]. In rat cells, Chinese skullcap protected against mitochondrial dysfunction caused by Antimycin A, a component of bacteria. It did so by reducing the free radical formation and promoting the activity of the electron transport chain [ [75](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22969827)]. We can't draw any conclusions about the health benefits of Chinese skullcap from cell-based studies. 26) Creatine [Creatine](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/creatine/) is a naturally occurring substance that plays a major role in the recycling of ATP in muscle and brain cells. Multiple cell studies have indicated that creatine is effective in restoring mitochondrial function, protecting against structural damage and oxidative stress, and reducing the impact of mitochondrial DNA mutations [ [76](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5005540/), [ 77](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4372859/), [ 78](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16098029)]. Animal and human studies are needed. 27) HMB [HMB](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/hmb-%CE%B2-hydroxy-%CE%B2-methylbutyrate-hmb/), or beta-hydroxy beta-methyl butyric acid, is an active breakdown product of the amino acid leucine. It is used as a supplement to prevent muscle protein loss. In 19 adults aged 60 to 70 with muscle loss during bed rest (RCT), HMB supplementation for 8 weeks restored mitochondrial function in skeletal muscles (higher levels of oxidative phosphorylation) [ [79](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28705993)]. HMB supplementation in skeletal muscle cells stimulated the production of proteins (PGC-1alpha) that increase the number of mitochondria per cell, overall improving skeletal muscle health [ [80](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26573541)]. However, another study of skeletal muscle cells indicated that HMB supplements had no effect on mitochondrial function or content. The purported benefits of HMB remain unproven [ [81](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27600148)]. 28) ALCAR [ALCAR](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/carnitine-top-18-science-based-health-effects-carnitine/), also known as acetylcarnitine, is a naturally occurring substance often used as a supplement. It's claimed to improve cognitive decline, aging, and blood vessel health. However, the evidence does not support these purported health benefits. ALCAR is considered a mitochondrial nutrient by some. Some theories claim that it can improve mitochondrial function by [ [82](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4120470/)]: - Protecting against oxidative stress - Reducing cell death (apoptosis) - Increasing mitochondrial generation - Improving the content of mitochondrial proteins In mice, ALCAR increased SIRT3 in the kidneys, thereby protecting against acute kidney injury and improving mitochondrial function [ [83](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25607838)]. In rats, ALCAR increased mitochondrial generation [ [84](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16814248)]. In a mouse model of fatty liver disease (non-alcoholic), coadministration of ALCAR and lipoic acid for 6 months reversed mitochondrial abnormalities and improved the size of mitochondria in the liver (mitochondrial fusion) [ [85](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24176233)]. 29) Danshen (Salvianolic acid A) Danshen comes from the roots of [ Salvia miltiorrhiza](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/salvia-miltiorrhiza-red-sage/) or red sage. It has been used historically in traditional Chinese medicine. In diabetic rats, danshen treatment for 3 weeks increased the activity of mitochondrial proteins (SIRT3, PGC-1alpha, and AMPK) involved in both the proper functioning of mitochondria and the generation of new mitochondria [ [86](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22996345)]. In rats with induced ischemic injury (loss of oxygen to tissue), pretreatment with danshen for 10 days before the injury prevented mitochondrial dysfunction by acting as an antioxidant. Danshen reduced oxidative damage and therefore improved cognitive function [ [87](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23748011)]. In heart cells, danshen prevented mitochondrial instability that leads to cell death [ [88](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23419388)]. More research is needed. 30) Caffeic acid Caffeic acid is an antioxidant molecule found in plants. In ischemic (loss of oxygen) rat kidney cells, caffeic acid reduced mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative damage. Additionally, it improved oxidative phosphorylation and prevented cell death (apoptosis) caused by the mitochondria [ [89](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5572631/)]. Similar improvements to energy dynamics by the mitochondria were seen in rat liver cells [ [90](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25960048)]. Human studies are needed. 31) EGCG (Green tea) [Green tea](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/green-tea/) is notorious for its alleged health benefits. Some scientists believe it can improve mitochondrial function. One of the main active ingredients, epigallocatechin gallate ( [EGCG](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/green-tea/)), accumulates within the of proteins (AMPK and PGC-1alpha) related to mitochondrial function and number [ [91](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26731017)]. In rats given the powdered green tea for 3 weeks, kidney function was restored after injury by improving the number and activity of mitochondrial proteins (PGC-1alpha and SIRT1/3) and increasing mitochondrial DNA levels [ [92](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3670924/)]. 32) Curcumin [Curcumin](https://supplements.selfdecode.com/blog/curcumin-cures-top-15-scientifically-proven-health-benefits-with-references/) is the active compound found in the spice turmeric. It has many purported health benefits. Due to the strong taste of turmeric and curcumin's poor bioavailability, it is often taken as a specialized supplement. In the livers and kidneys of diabetic mice, curcumin supplementation for 4 weeks restored mitochondrial function by [ [93](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4289591/)]: - Increasing ATPase activity - Coupling oxygen consumption to energy production - Restoring nitric oxide synthesis - Decreasing blood glucose levels In rats injected with curcumin for 28 days, increased numbers of mitochondria were observed in skeletal muscle cells after exercise. They claim it also acts as an artificial electron donor to complex I-IV of the mitochondria. However, no evidence backs them up. Limited research suggests that MB may increase heme synthesis, cytochrome c oxidase (complex IV), and mitochondrial respiration [ [99](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20463399)], all of which help cognitive function. This means that it can increase ATP production, in theory. However, its effects in humans remain unknown. ATP is the currency of life and the energy that powers humans. If our production of ATP declines, our physical and mental performance declines. Even healthy individuals may benefit from a boost in ATP production, according to some people. However, high concentrations of methylene blue promote [ oxidative stress](https://health.selfdecode.com/blog/oxidative-stress-101/). In fact, at high local concentrations, methylene blue can potentially "steal" electrons away from the electron transport chain complexes, disrupting the redox balance and acting as a pro-oxidant [ [100](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3265679/#R114)]. At low concentrations, methylene blue can interact with oxygen to form water, which would decrease the superoxide radicals produced during the process of oxidative phosphorylation. Some scientists think MB can also trap leaking electrons produced by mitochondrial inhibitors and preserve the metabolic rate by bypassing blocked points of electron flow, thus improving mitochondrial respiration. This theory remains unproven [ [101](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3265679/#R61), [ 102](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3265679/#R101), [ 103](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3265679/#R124)]. In a rat model of cerebral ischemia, methylene blue was able to speed up the removal of damaged mitochondria from a cell prior to cell death (mitophagy) [ [104](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25998511)]. Additionally, in rat models of pancreatitis, methylene blue reduced mitochondrial dysfunction [ [105](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26861116)].
